Article.ArticleTitle: Rothia santali sp. nov., endophytic bacteria isolated from sandalwood (Santalum album L.) seedling.

AbstractText: A novel, mustard yellow-pigmented aerobic bacterial strain designated AR01<sup>T</sup> was isolated from hypocotyl tissue of a sandalwood seedling from Bangalore, India. The 16S rRNA gene of strain AR01<sup>T</sup> had the highest 98.97% sequence similarity with Rothia halotolerans YIM 90716<sup>T</sup> (KCTC 19172) followed by Rothia kristinae PM 129<sup>T</sup> (NBRC 15354<sup>T</sup>) (97.31%) and Rothia koreensis P31<sup>T</sup> (JCM 15915) (97.11%), respectively. The strain AR01<sup>T</sup> was coccoid-shaped, non-motile, non-spore forming, oxidase negative and catalase positive. The strain AR01<sup>T</sup> has a genome size of 3.31 Mb containing 2993 protein-coding genes including 48 tRNA and 10 rRNAs spread across 84 contigs. The genomic DNA G + C content was 71.77 mol%. The calculated dDDH was 31.10% and the OrthoANI value was 85.27% when compared with its closest related type strain Rothia halotolerans YIM 90716<sup>T</sup>. The predominant cellular fatty acids were C<sub>16:0 iso</sub>, C<sub>15:0 anteiso</sub> and C<sub>17:0 anteiso</sub>. The strain AR01<sup>T</sup> contains major polar lipids including diphosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylglycerol. The distinct physiological, biochemical characteristics and genotypic relatedness indicated that AR01<sup>T</sup> represents a novel species of the genus Rothia, for which the name Rothia santali sp. nov. (Type strain AR01<sup>T</sup> = MCC 4800<sup>T</sup> = JCM 35593<sup>T</sup>) is proposed.
